pulltitle: Update the README to include the text from the Code of Conduct
pullsbody:
Rather than using a link to the Code of Conduct, I just included it verbatim as it's short.

This solution isn't DRY, but forcing users to visit a link for a couple of sentences which are themselves just a link, didn't seem very friendly.
pull_repo_desc: Proposals for future Firefox browser architecture
pull_commit_message: Update the README to include the text from the Code of Conduct

pulltitle: Add Mozilla Code of Conduct
pullsbody:
Fixes #76


As of January 1 2019, Mozilla requires that all GitHub projects include this [CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md](https://github.com/mozilla/repo-templates/blob/master/templates/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md) file in the project root. The file has two parts:

1. Required Text - All text under the headings *Community Participation Guidelines and How to Report*, are required, and should not be altered.
2. Optional Text - The Project Specific Etiquette heading provides a space to speak more specifically about ways people can work effectively and inclusively together. Some examples of those can be found on the [Firefox Debugger](https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md) project, and [Common Voice](https://github.com/mozilla/voice-web/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md). (The optional part is commented out in the [raw template file](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mozilla/repo-templates/blob/master/templates/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md), and will not be visible until you modify and uncomment that part.)

If you have any questions about this file, or Code of Conduct policies and procedures, please see [Mozilla-GitHub-Standards](https://wiki.mozilla.org/GitHub/Repository_Requirements) or email Mozilla-GitHub-Standards+CoC@mozilla.com.

_(Message COC002)_
pull_repo_desc: Proposals for future Firefox browser architecture
pull_commit_message:
Add Mozilla Code of Conduct file

Fixes #76.

_(Message COC002)_

pulltitle: link to original article on public web
pullsbody: This document originally linked to a copy of https://symas.com/understanding-lmdb-database-file-sizes-and-memory-utilization/ in a private Google Docs page, since the original web page wasn't loading. But the page/server has been fixed, and since this doc is public, all the pages it references should also be public.
pull_repo_desc: Proposals for future Firefox browser architecture
pull_commit_message:
link to original article on public web

This document originally linked to a copy of https://symas.com/understanding-lmdb-database-file-sizes-and-memory-utilization/ in a private Google Docs page, since the original web page wasn't loading. But the page/server has been fixed, and since this doc is public, all the pages it references should also be public.

pulltitle: publish comparison between LMDB and LevelDB
pullsbody:
@joewalker This is a Markdown version of the Google Doc I wrote a few months ago to compare LMDB and LevelDB. I tried to format it in the same two-column format I used in the Google Doc, with a side-by-side comparison of the two storage engines within each section; but GitHub-flavored Markdown makes that hard, so I eventually gave up and restructured the doc to describe first LMDB and then LevelDB within each section. Is there anything else that you recommend we change about the content or formatting of this doc?

@ncalexan You previously looked at the Google Doc and had some feedback, after which I made some changes. I've since added another footnote about Wikipedia reliability and the use of it as one (but not the only) source of information about the two storage engines. Is there anything you would change before we publish this?
pull_repo_desc: Proposals for future Firefox browser architecture
pull_commit_message: publish comparison between LMDB and LevelDB

pulltitle: fix indentation of list hierarchies
pullsbody:
Apparently child list items must be indented at least as much as their parent item's *text*, which is at least three spaces for numbered parent items, as those are prefixed with three characters: a number (f.e. "1"), a period ("."), and a space (" ").

Thus two-space indentation of child items:

```
1. Foo
  * bar
  * baz
```

Fails to indent the children:

1. Foo
  * bar
  * baz

While three-space indentation:

```
1. Foo
   * bar
   * baz
```

Successfully indents the children:

1. Foo
   * bar
   * baz

Three spaces is arguably uglier than an even amount of indentation when editing the raw text (especially if your text editor assumes even indentation), so this change indents the children of numbered items by *four* characters and the children of bulleted items by *two* characters.

It also makes the bulleting characters more consistent, using an asterisk (*) for a first-level bulleted item, a dash (-) for a second-level item, and a plus sign (+) for a third-level item. (This doesn't affect appearance, as all three bulleting characters result in the same bullets, which vary only by level.)

This PR makes no textual changes. It is strictly formatting.
pull_repo_desc: Proposals for future Firefox browser architecture

pulltitle: Doc updates and minor code sample changes
pullsbody:
Apologies in advance for my trigger-happy editors (seems like it's all of them) which declared war on dangling white-space.

As I was going through this post:
- a couple of things confused me a bit
  - see a couple of minor edits to paragraphs and making the `<project_path>` to be consistent in the post
- Rust code didn't actually compile
  - it didn't understand what `rust_greeting_free(world);` was, and that seemed like ungoogleable black magic to me as well
  - According to https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/ffi/struct.CString.html#method.into_raw, my changes should work correctly (and they appear to)
- and once it did compile, it produced a library in `rlib` format, whereas we need an `so`
  - figured out that I can be explicit about the library type!
  - I suspect that this is because I'm running through this on Linux
pull_repo_desc: Proposals for future Firefox browser architecture

pulltitle: Doc updates and minor code sample changes
pullsbody:
Apologies in advance for my trigger-happy editors (seems like it's all of them) which declared war on dangling white-space.

As I was going through this post:
- a couple of things confused me a bit
  - see a couple of minor edits to paragraphs and making the `<project_path>` to be consistent in the post
- Rust code didn't actually compile
  - it didn't understand what `rust_greeting_free(world);` was, and that seemed like ungoogleable black magic to me as well
  - According to https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/ffi/struct.CString.html#method.into_raw, my changes should work correctly (and they appear to)
- and once it did compile, it produced a library in `rlib` format, whereas we need an `so`
  - figured out that I can be explicit about the library type!
  - I suspect that this is because I'm running through this on Linux
pull_repo_desc: Proposals for future Firefox browser architecture
pull_commit_message: Explicitly declare crate_type; clean up pointers.

pull_commit_message:
Minor tweaks: unsmartify quotes and unembolden least

Use normal quotes, Markdown smartifies quotes for us.
We're no longer saying *most* senior in the next sentence so it doesn't
make sense for us to emphasize *least*.

pull_commit_message:
Phrase the review as a proposal rather than a question.

We started doing this a few changes back to make the review less of a
confrontation, but some wording remained

pulltitle: Brief should identify review that has already happened.
pullsbody: I think this is helpful for identifying gaps.  For example, if the team notes that they've talked to two other teams about their design, that might prompt some of the reviewers (or the team itself, as they write the brief) to notice that there's a third team that they also need to talk to.
pull_repo_desc: Proposals for future Firefox browser architecture
pull_commit_message:
Brief should identify review that has already happened.

I think this is helpful for identifying gaps.  For example, if the team
notes that they've talked to two other teams about their design, that
might prompt some of the reviewers (or the team itself, as they write
the brief) to notice that there's a third team that they also need to
talk to.

pulltitle: Add note that the output of a design review should - fix for #26
pullsbody:
This originated from a [discussion](https://docs.google.com/a/mozilla.com/document/d/14YvP3e3OL6lo1D_l15sboUs46M80F9DDE12YoWpjtq0/edit?disco=AAAABFzXKBU) in the design review packet, in which we suggested that the proposal should be detailed enough to work as an input into a bug breakdown process in which a set of high-level features / design changes are broken down into many individual engineering work items that can be tracked and tackled one by one (as is done with the Photon work, for instance). The format of a breakdown bug isn't really specified anywhere that I'm aware of, but in bugzilla terms it's generally a metabug that gets blocked by bugs that get filed by the engineering team at the start of a project. Here are a few examples that it can take the shape of:

* Breaking down performance work: [Doorhanger opening transitions are janky](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1252224)
* Breaking down a UI feature: [Update the hamburger panel for Photon](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1352695)

The addition to the doc is in https://github.com/mozilla/firefox-browser-architecture/commit/aaed9f665a3b1235a21d7b26d1cf4b1a00960df7, the two prior commits are shuffling around and re-wording to make the change easier (but feel free to review the squashed version as well).
pull_repo_desc: Proposals for future Firefox browser architecture
pull_commit_message: Move the RACI paragraph in Outputs section up to be clear that it applies to both Design and Roadmap reviews

pulltitle: Create 2017-08-24-browser-architecture-newsletter-2.md
pullsbody:
Here are the steps I used to generate this from docs and into firefox-dev / PR:

Paste content from docs into https://html-cleaner.com/
Take generated HTML and paste into mail client to send message
Take generated HTML and paste into https://domchristie.github.io/to-markdown/ to generate markdown for the PR
Add `[Link to mailing-list archive](URL)` (where URL is the permalink on groups.google.com) at the top of the .md file in the PR
pull_repo_desc: Proposals for future Firefox browser architecture

pulltitle: clarify proposal and conclusion
pullsbody:
Per [my recent comment in a thread on the original pull request](https://github.com/mozilla/firefox-browser-architecture/pull/2#discussion_r134298508), I think we should revisit the titles of the Problem and Proposal sections, and the structure of the text in the Problem section, in this document. Specifically:
* rename Problem section to Proposal
* change "problem statement" from question to assertion
* rename Proposal section to Conclusion
pull_repo_desc: Proposals for future Firefox browser architecture
pull_commit_message:
clarify proposal and conclusion

Per [my recent comment in a thread on the original pull request](https://github.com/mozilla/firefox-browser-architecture/pull/2#discussion_r134298508), I think we should revisit the titles of the Problem and Proposal sections, and the structure of the text in the Problem section, in this document. Specifically:
* rename Problem section to Proposal
* change "problem statement" from question to assertion
* rename Proposal section to Conclusion
